sentences: Tenitra Michelle Williams was born in Rockford, Illinois, on July 23, 1979, to Anita Williams (née Washington) and Dennis Williams III (1952–2020).
section: == Life and career == | === 1979–1999: Early life ===

sentences: She has three siblings: elder brother Erron, who is also a musician, elder sister Cameron, and younger sister Danielle.
section: == Life and career == | === 1979–1999: Early life ===

sentences: Williams made her musical debut at the age of seven, performing a rendition of the hymn "Blessed Assurance" at the St. Paul Church of God in Christ.
section: == Life and career == | === 1979–1999: Early life ===

sentences: She later sang in the gospel groups United Harmony and Chosen Expression.
section: == Life and career == | === 1979–1999: Early life ===

sentences: Williams graduated from Rockford Auburn High School in 1997.
section: == Life and career == | === 1979–1999: Early life ===

sentences: Shortly after graduating, she pursued a degree in criminal justice at Illinois State University, doubtful of her ability to make a career as a professional singer.
section: == Life and career == | === 1979–1999: Early life ===

sentences: However, after two years of college, she left to pursue a music career, as a backing vocalist for other artists such as Monica.
section: == Life and career == | === 1979–1999: Early life ===

sentences: In late 1999, 20-year-old Williams met Destiny's Child band members Beyoncé and Kelly Rowland in the lobby of an Atlanta hotel.
section: == Life and career == | === 1979–1999: Early life ===

sentences: Several months later, a choreographer acquaintance of Williams who knew the group connected Williams to the Knowles family and Rowland, as they were vetting potential new group members.

sentences: After the much-publicized turmoil, Williams, alongside backup dancer Farrah Franklin, officially joined the group in early 2000, replacing LeToya Luckett and LaTavia Roberson without notice.

sentences: On December 7, 2018, Williams released the pop single "Fearless" on Radiance Music Group.
section: == Life and career == | === 2015–present: "Fearless", continued acting, The Masked Singer and upcoming projects ===

sentences: On December 21, 2018, it was announced by Deadline Hollywood that Williams would guest star as Diana Ross in an episode of the BET period drama series American Soul, which aired in February 2019.
section: == Life and career == | === 2015–present: "Fearless", continued acting, The Masked Singer and upcoming projects ===

sentences: In April 2019, the singer was involved in Beyoncé's documentary Homecoming and homonymous album.
section: == Life and career == | === 2015–present: "Fearless", continued acting, The Masked Singer and upcoming projects ===

sentences: Later that year, Williams competed as "Butterfly" in the second season of The Masked Singer.

sentences: In December 2019, she came back to the stage starring as the Evil Queen for the 10th anniversary of A Snow White Christmas at the Pasadena Civic Auditorium, alongside Neil Patrick Harris and Jared Gertner.
section: == Life and career == | === 2015–present: "Fearless", continued acting, The Masked Singer and upcoming projects ===

sentences: In November 2020, Williams announced her memoir, Checking In: How Getting Real About Depression Saved My Life–and Can Save Yours, which was released in May 2021.
section: == Life and career == | === 2015–present: "Fearless", continued acting, The Masked Singer and upcoming projects ===

sentences: The accompanying podcast, Checking In with Michelle Williams, premiered on streaming services in December 2020.
section: == Life and career == | === 2015–present: "Fearless", continued acting, The Masked Singer and upcoming projects ===

== Artistry ==

sentences: Artistry ==
section: == Artistry ==
== Artistry == | === Voice ===

sentences: Voice =
section: == Artistry == | === Voice ===
== Artistry == | === Voice ===

sentences: Williams can be identified as a soprano.
section: == Artistry == | === Voice ===

sentences: William Ruhlmann of AllMusic commented that she has a "warm, kittenish voice" with the ability to "transform" from "kitten to tiger", belting "with absolute conviction".
section: == Artistry == | === Voice ===

sentences: GospelMusicCity.com praised her "delicate vocals" and described her "sopralto stylings" as "inimitable", writing that on "Heard a Word" she "demonstrates further versatility in Ella-like fashion".
section: == Artistry == | === Voice ===

sentences: Sal Cinquemani of Slant Magazine also compared her to other singers writing; "Williams's warm vocal recalls both the playful wisps of her R&B contemporaries (Jill Scott, Erykah Badu) and the breathy timbre of Diana Ross" while Emily Sogn of PopMatters wrote "Williams singing style is pleasingly slow paced...that owes a lot to her pop contemporaries like Ashanti and Janet Jackson."
section: == Artistry == | === Voice ===

sentences: Similarly, Mike Rimmer of Cross Rhythms described her voice as "soulful" and Caroline Sullivan of The Guardian wrote that "Williams's strength is a shimmery jazz lilt".
section: == Artistry == | === Voice ===

sentences: Honors and awards ==
section: == Honors and awards ==

sentences: Williams has earned an array of awards and honors as a solo artist and a member of Destiny's Child.
section: == Honors and awards ==

sentences: These include: one Grammy Award and one MOBO Award.
section: == Honors and awards ==

sentences: Billboard ranked Williams as the fifth Top Gospel Artist of 2002 due to the success of her debut release Heart to Yours which was one of the best-selling gospel releases of the year.
section: == Honors and awards ==

sentences: In 2013, Williams was honored in her hometown of Rockford, Illinois at the 2013 I Love Gospel Music honors luncheon, which featured musical tributes, including one by Sunday Best winner Amber Bullock.

sentences: Williams has a history of depression, saying that she has "been suffering since the ages of 13 and 15".
section: == Personal life == | === Mental health ===

sentences: During her time with Destiny's Child, she says that she told their then manager Mathew Knowles about her feelings, but that he  did not really understand.
section: == Personal life == | === Mental health ===

sentences: He replied to her concerns by trying to point out the good side of their new-found fame, "You all just signed a multi-millionaire dollar deal, you're about to go on tour, what have you got to be depressed about?"
section: == Personal life == | === Mental health ===

sentences: She said that she had difficulty understanding her own feelings until later in life, around her thirties, stating that "I didn't know until I was in my 30s what was going on, I just thought it was growing pains, I just thought I'm turning into a woman."
section: == Personal life == | === Mental health ===

sentences: She also felt that Knowles intended no malice, and only had her best interests at heart, "Bless his heart...

sentences: I think he wanted me to be grateful, which I was, but I was still sad.
section: == Personal life == | === Mental health ===

sentences: "Williams again felt helpless after she and her fiancé, Chad Johnson, split up in late 2018.

sentences: The rage built up in me.

== Personal life == | ==== Memoir ====

sentences: In November 2020, Williams announced plans to release a memoir "revealing her entire truth including a deeper dive into where her anxiety and depression came from."
section: == Personal life == | ==== Memoir ====

sentences: She stated, "I'm ready to share, I've been a very transparent person and now I'm ready to share the good, bad, and ugly parts of my journey—the concerning part of my journey. ...
section: == Personal life == | ==== Memoir ====

sentences: I really go into the specifics, I really go into the first time I was diagnosed, I go into assessing the first time I had anxiety in a romantic relationship and what it did to that relationship and then subsequently what it did to the next one."
section: == Personal life == | ==== Memoir ====

sentences: Williams said she hoped to "really help heal through my story" and "let people know what I do on a daily, what I do on a monthly–whatever it takes to get people whole and get people where they can maybe start seeing some better results in their own life.
section: == Personal life == | ==== Memoir ====

sentences: "The book titled Checking In: How Getting Real about Depression Saved My Life—and Can Save Yours was published on May 25, 2021.

== Philanthropy ==

sentences: Philanthropy ==
section: == Philanthropy ==

sentences: In 2001, Williams made a "bountiful" donation of $148,900 to her church, St. Paul Church of God in Christ in Rockford, Illinois – of which she has been a member since birth – to finish construction of the church's school, St. Paul Academy.
section: == Philanthropy ==

sentences: The church is pastored by her uncle, Bishop James E. Washington.
section: == Philanthropy ==

sentences: In 2005, music producer David Foster, his daughter Amy Foster-Gillies, and Knowles wrote "Stand Up for Love", which would serve as the anthem of World Children's Day, an event which takes place annually around the world on November 20 to raise awareness and funds for children's causes worldwide.
section: == Philanthropy ==

sentences: Destiny's Child lent their voices and support as global ambassadors for the 2005 World Children's Day program.
section: == Philanthropy ==

sentences: In this role, Knowles, Rowland and Williams visited Ronald McDonald Houses around the world during their Destiny Fulfilled... and Lovin' It World Tour and donated a portion of their North American ticket sales to Ronald McDonald House Charities.
section: == Philanthropy ==

sentences: On September 19, 2006, Williams jump-started the Chicago PepsiCo S.M.A.R.T. – which stands for five simple steps that encourage active living and better food choices – program to promote active, healthy lifestyles by building a new "Smart Spot" playground in Chicago.
section: == Philanthropy ==

sentences: Williams, along with friend Lance Bass, was on hand to sing to and greet kids at the opening of Camp Heartland, a camp dedicated to helping kids suffering from HIV/AIDS enjoy life and take their mind off their illness.
section: == Philanthropy ==

sentences: Furthermore, in 2006, the Chicago Sky, a team in the Women's National Basketball Association, announced that Williams, along with Mathew Knowles, is part of a group of minority shareholder owners in the team.
section: == Philanthropy ==

sentences: In 2012, she became an ambassador for the American Heart Association's Power to End Stroke campaign.
section: == Philanthropy ==

sentences: In speaking of her role she said "I am honored to partner with the campaign ...
section: == Philanthropy ==

sentences: my father had a stroke in 2005 due to smoking, diabetes and an unhealthy diet, and my grandmother was diagnosed with having a stroke in 2006 when she went to her doctor for a simple outpatient procedure.
section: == Philanthropy ==

sentences: I am bringing awareness to people so that strokes can be prevented.
section: == Philanthropy ==

sentences: Let's take care of ourselves...the first step is knowledge about your health.
section: == Philanthropy ==

sentences: "In 2014, Williams partnered with Hyundai's non-profit organization, Hope on Wheels, "committed to finding a cure for childhood cancer"; which has raised over $74,000,000 for the cause since its inception in 1998.
